item.title: Terror Attacks on New Zealand Mosques Kill 49
item.description: A 28-year-old man was charged with murder after shootings at two mosques in the southern city of Christchurch in terrorist attacks the prime minister described as one of the darkest days in the country’s history. Police are investigating if there was more than one attacker involved.

item.title: Brazil Government Doubles Down on Pro-Gun Stance After School Shooting
item.description: As Brazil reels from one of its worst school shootings, the response from President Jair Bolsonaro’s administration and his supporters this week has echoed one heard in the U.S.: What Brazil needs, they say, is more guns.

item.title: U.S. Swipes at International Court Over Afghanistan Investigations
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the U.S. is imposing visa restrictions against International Criminal Court officials, citing investigations by the ICC into the activities of Americans and their allies in Afghanistan.

item.title: Russian Tycoon Deripaska Sues U.S.
item.description: Russian aluminum tycoon Oleg Deripaska sued the Trump administration over sanctions it imposed on him and his companies last year, claiming it made false allegations based on rumor to support the sanctions.

item.title: North Korea Threatens to Exit Nuclear Talks
item.description: A senior North Korean official warned that the country may suspend talks with the U.S. over its nuclear arsenal, in the latest sign of pressure on Washington.

item.title: Massive Protests Present Big Test for Secretive Algerian Government
item.description: Massive protests have spotlighted Algeria’s style of governance, as President Abdelaziz Bouteflika’s circle struggles to navigate the country’s most serious crisis since a devastating civil war in the 1990s.
